titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of Charles Patrick McKone at the Veterans History Project
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Evelyn B. Green

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2010-06-03T17:11-0400

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: This Collection describes Charles McKone’s military experience during the Vietnam War. A one hour and eleven minute oral history interview was conducted on January 29, 2004 at Central Connecticut State University by Eileen Hurst, Associate Director of CCSU’s Center for Public Policy and Social Research. Along with Mr. McKone’s taped interview the Collection includes a typed interview synopsis.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Born March 17, 1947 Charles Patrick McKone was drafted into the Army in July of 1968. After receiving Advanced Individual Training (AIT) at Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri he went on to attend Officer Candidate School at Fort Jackson, South Carolina. Following a brief stint in Germany Captain McKone was assigned as Company Commander of Military Assistance Command Vietnam Special Troops (MACV) in Saigon. A recipient of the Bronze Star, Charles was honorably discharged in July of 1973.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: For permission to publish please contact Central Connecticut State University’s Center for Public Policy and Social Research at (860) 832-2976.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Charles Patrick McKone Papers. VHP2004/1. Veterans History Project; Central Connecticut State University, Center for Public Policy and Social Research

altformavail.head: Online Access
altformavail.p: An Online exhibition of this veteran's papers can be accessed at project's website

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged based on content and material type into 2 series:

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: All manuscripts and photographs donated were digitized then archived digitally. The donor retained all original manuscripts and photographs.
